In the middle of the palace itself, a great and splendid building. It contains 20 great and handsome halls, one of which is more spacious than the rest, and affords room for a vast multitude to dine. Before Marco Polo told his tales, these lands in the f arthest reaches of the world seemed like the stuff of fantasy and myth to the Europeans. Inside the city there is a Lake which has a compass of some 30 miles: and all around it are erected beautiful palaces and mansions, of the richest and most esquisite structure that you can imagine, belonging to the nobles of the city....In the middle of the Lake are two Islands, on each of which stands a rich, beautiful and spacious edifice, furnished in such style as to seem fit for the palace of an Emperor: And when any one of the citizens desired to hold a marraige feast, or to give any other entertainmeant, it used to be done at one of these palaces.
